The "Student Loan Debt Protection Act of 2015" includes provisions for the dischargeability of student loans in bankruptcy cases and reinstatement of the 6-year statute of limitations for student loans. The "Student Loan Debt Protection Act of 2015" reinstates the 6-year statute of limitations for student loans, allowing institutions to take action for refund collection within this period. Guaranty agencies with agreements with the Secretary can also initiate collection actions within the same timeframe. The Secretary or institutions with agreements can file a suit for collection of student loan amounts within a 6-year period after borrower default. The Secretary or institutions can file a suit for collection of student loan amounts within a 6-year period after borrower default, excluding periods where the statute of limitations is tolled under State law. PROHIBITION OF COLLECTION OF STUDENT LOANS THROUGH OFFSETS OR WAGE GARNISHMENT. Prohibition on offset of Social Security benefits and tax refunds under certain circumstances. Prohibition on offset of Social Security benefits and tax refunds under certain circumstances. Any Federal agency shall not notify an individual of past-due debt owed to the Department of Education under certain programs, and tax refunds shall not be reduced for such debt. Wage garnishment prohibition is also amended under title 31, United States Code. Any delinquent nontax debt owed to the Department of Education under certain programs shall not be collected through garnishment of an individual's disposable pay. TITLE II--BORROWER'S RIGHT TO REASONABLE AND FLEXIBLE REPAYMENT OPTIONS

SEC. 201. EXCLUSION FROM GROSS INCOME FOR DISCHARGE OF STUDENT LOAN INDEBTEDNESS.

Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude student loan indebtedness from gross income when discharged. Includes refinanced student loan debt in the definition of student loans.

Effective Date: Applies to discharges of indebtedness after the enactment of this Act.

SEC. 202. 529 PLAN DISTRIBUTION FOR STUDENT LOAN PAYMENTS. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for interest or principal payments on qualified education loans to be made for a designated beneficiary. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to distributions made after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 203.
